note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be far-sided or related to slow field line movement visible near the southern limb in SDO AIA 171, 193, 304 imagery starting around 2024-07-31T22:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery. The source is likely an M6.3 flare and eruption from Active Region 13773 (S07W60) starting at 2024-08-01T01:49Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Field line movement is visible near the western limb at this time in SDO AIA 171 as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location. This event is too faint to measure confidently in STEREO A COR2 imagery, so this measurement relies on SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery only. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible as a partial halo to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery. The source is an M8.2 flare and eruption from Active Region 13768 (S15W80) starting around 2024-08-01T07:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. A wide opening of field lines is visible in GOES SUVI 171, 195, and 284 imagery at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the bulk portion based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraphs. The measured longitude deflects about 15 degrees from the source location, and multiple measurements produced speeds ranging from 1092 km/s to 1120 km/s.
Measurement of the shock front based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption and M4.1 flare from Active Region 13772 (S25E41) starting around 2024-08-01T11:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: The first in a 2-CME series. This CME is associated with the earlier movement of field lines seen in AIA 171 behind the limb in the NE. This first movement starts at 2024-08-01T20:54Z, as seen in AIA 171. Its source could be the X4 class flare registered by STIX instrument on the Solar Orbiter at 2024-08-01T20:50Z and seen on the west limb, as seen by Solar Orbiter.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate measurement based on a fit with two coronagraphs. The source is behind the NE limb.

note: A second CME in a 2-CME series of closely following relatively narrow CMEs. Light-bulb shaped CME quickly catching up (by 2024-08-02T01:00Z) the earlier narrower CME. The source of this CME is a relatively faint movement of field lines in the NE behind the limb, as seen in AIA 171/193 and in SUVI 171/284 starting at 2024-08-01T22:10Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Re-analysis based on the interpretation of these two consequtive fronts as two separate CMEs with distinct sources seen behind the limb in the NE. Analysis is approximate, based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. Longitude can vary (+-10 degrees).
Approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraph. The source is behind the limb and its longitude is uncertain.

note: Faint CME seen to the NNE in all coronagraphs, though becomes quite faint in SOHO LASCO C3/ later frames of STEREO COR2A. The likely source for this CME is a sputtering eruption from AR 3775 beginning around 2024-08-02T00:42Z, seen as field line movement and some material flowing out along field lines in SDO AIA 171, but not in a crisp clean eruptive motion. More evidence for this source comes from a broad post-eruptive arcade over the region forming around 2024-08-02T02:24Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A using AR 3775 as a source, finding a good fit deflected northward. This front is very faint and diffuses late in C2 and COR2A frames, and is barely visible in C3, so some uncertainly lies in tracking the true front as it fizzles.

note: Wide, bright CME to the W in all coronagraphs. Source is an eruption from AR 3768 beginning around 2024-08-02T04:27Z, observed as wide field line movement, EUV wave, and a following post-eruptive arcade in SDO AIA 171/193/211/304 and GOES SUVI 171/195/284. Accompanied by a long-duration M7.4 flare which peaked at 2024-08-02T04:55Z, observed best in SDO AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement, triangulated between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A using the source of the eruption from AR 3768 around S14W88 as the source, finding a good fit slightly deflected eastward. This CME front is a bit lopsided to the northern end, so this fit best tracking the leading edge misses some material on the southern portion of the leading edge.

note: Faint, wispy CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs. The source is not distinct in SDO imagery, but is likely attributed to activity from cluster of active regions present in the SW at this time, including AR 3768 which produced numerous other eruptions in the past 48 hours. This CME also triangulated well to W90 during measurement, further corroborating a source on/very near the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement at W90 between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, not an official plane-of-sky measurement. The distinct source longitude is not clear, but W90 triangulated well, so the longitude is likely within W80-W110 favoring front-sided due to the cluster of numerous active regions.

note: Faint but distinct loop CME seen to the S/SE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2. The time at which this CME first enters the C2 field of view is probably a bit earlier than 06:48Z, but the leading edge is not clearly discernable in C2 imagery (both white light and difference imagery) in any frames before 06:48Z when it is about halfway through the C2 field of view. The exact source location is uncertain due to the faintness of the event, but the strongest candidate source is a set of loops of field lines seen in the SE quadrant of the disk, which showed movement (and possible ejection of some material) starting around 2024-08-03T03:30Z. These loops of field lines in the SE span from E40 to E80, and their footpoints appear to be anywhere from S10-S25 and are tilted south.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using best fit between C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Many frames of both C3 and STEREO A COR2 were able to be used. Leading edge is faint, but trackable.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to field line movement visible near or slightly beyond the northwest limb starting around 2024-08-04T07:14Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery. The source is likely an eruption from Active Region 13778 (S20W72) starting around 2024-08-04T11:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge of this event becomes too diffuse to measure after a few frames, so this measurement relies on early imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided, and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the southeast limb starting around 2024-08-04T14:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, and GOES SUVI 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the uncertain/far-sided source location.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely related to an eruption and M2.2 flare from an unnumbered region centered near S10E89 starting around 2024-08-04T15:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location. Because there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 during this event, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: A very faint narrow CME in the NE seen in SOHO LASCO and mostly covered by a data gap in STEREO COR2. Its source could possibly be a faint movement/opening of field lines behind the limb starting between 2024-08-04T17:30Z and 17:57Z, as seen in SUVI 284 and AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very speculative analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs, however there are only two images in STEREO COR2 that possibly show the front of this CME after the data gap and the front in COR2 is super faint. The source of this CME is behind the limb, so the longitude is very approximate.

note: This faint CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is possibly related to a small eruption and M1.0 flare from Active Region 13780 (S10E64) starting around 2024-08-04T22:10Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, and 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approx. source location and best fit between C2 and COR2A. Leading edge becomes diffuse after about 3 frames in C3 difference imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption and M1.1 flare from Active Region 13780 (S10E61) starting around 2024-08-05T02:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, and 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption and M6.1 flare from Active Region 13780 (S10E60) starting around 2024-08-05T05:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, and 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

Bright and wide CME with the source an X1.7 class flare from just behind the west limb, possibly from Active Region 3795 that rotated behind the limb on the previous day. The flare is seen close to the west limb in EUVI A imagery. The associated eruption is seen right after the flare in AIA/SUVI 304, with wide opening field lines and massive restructuring of magnetic field on/behind the limb seen in AIA 193/171 and in SUVI 193/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the location of the potential source of the flare and eruption - Active Region 3765 and confirmed by a good fit in two coronagraphs with this longitude. The source is behind the limb, but is seen on disk in EUVI STEREO A.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely an eruption and X1.1 flare from Active Region 13780 (S10E55) starting around 2024-08-05T15:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery, there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: A very faint NE CME only seen in SOHO LASCO C2 and a few timestamps of C3 coronagraph and covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. Event is very faint in white light imagery, but is better seen in difference imagery. No clear source was found on disk, but there is a slow movement of two field lines behind the NE limb starting after 2024-08-05T17Z as seen in AIA 171, possibly indicating a backsided source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Because the source is behind the limb and the CME is only seen in one coronagraph (SOHO) only plane of sky measurement is possible.

note: Small filament eruption seen to the NW in all coronagraphs. The source is a small filament close to AR 3775 spanning approx. N12W10<->N15W20 at 2024-08-06-23:03Z before it began to slowly rise, more explosively erupting around 2024-08-07T01:02Z. Best observed in SDO AIA 304 as the filament material ejecting, but also seen in SDO AIA 171/193/211 as field line movement, in SDO AIA 304 as brightening on the surface, and a post-eruptive arcade forming around 2024-08-07T02:12Z across all wavelengths.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 with STEREO COR2A, using the source filament as a guide, finding some northward deflection.

note: CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-07T03:24Z as well as in later frames of C3 and STEREO A COR2. This CME appears very faint in white light imagery. The best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A indicate that this event may originate from the vicinity of S15E30, however there is no definitive source seen on the disk for this event. There are a number of speculative sources including field line loop movement and brightening from AR 3781 (S13E42) as seen in SDO AIA 94.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint CME seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an eruption seen on the northeast limb at about N17E90 in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284. Field line movement and a small bright loop can be seen as early as 2024-08-07T00:38Z in GOES SUVI 284 and 2024-08-07T00:58Z in SDO AIA 193. The small loop of field lines that brighten is located at an apparent latitude of N17 and is on or very close to the East limb. There are faint opening field lines surrounding this loop seen in SDO AIA 193 starting at roughly 2024-08-07T01:03Z and extending from apparent latitudes of about S05 to N20 on the E limb. The exact location of source may possibly extend beyond the E limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between multiple frames of C2, C3, and COR2A, as well as location of candidate source on the NE limb. Leading edge is faint in STEREO A COR2 and becomes diffuse before reaching halfway through C3 field of view.

note: Faint and narrow CME first seen by SOHO LASCO C2 in the NW beginning at 2024-08-07T03:48Z as well as by C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. Possible source is a C8.5 flare from N05W85 peaking at 2024-08-07T02:01Z as seen in SDO AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2024-08-07T14:09Z. Eruption with M4.5 flare from AR 3774 (approx. S10W22), field line movement, and possible faint EUV wave visible in SDO AIA 193. Opening field lines are best seen in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284. The eruption is also visible from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location. Limited imagery was used in SOHO LASCO C3 due to the CME's faintness.

note: Backsided halo CME visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 in real-time due to a data gap from 2024-08-07T14:09Z. The source is not seen in available EUV imagery, and is believed to be backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using fit on back side in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2. Because this is based on the best fit of the halo in SOHO only, the longitude is very approximate.

note: CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an M5.0 flare peaking at 2024-08-07T18:54Z from AR 3777. The start of the CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-08-07T17:23Z to 23:09Z. Dimming, opening field lines are seen in SDO AIA 193, and the eruption appears to be directed towards the southeast. A possible faint, separate halo component may also be seen in early frames of SOHO LASCO C2.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and a late frame of STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-08T04:48Z as well as in later frames by STEREO A COR2. This event is not clearly visible in SOHO LASCO C3 as it may be too faint or obscured by the pylon. Possible source is wider field line opening seen beyond the NW limb in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Outflow CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-08T05:12Z, as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this eruption/outflow may be the continuous movement and restructuring of field lines between ARs 3780 (S09E25) and 3777 (S09W08) as seen in SDO AIA 94.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. This event was too faint to be measured with SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Faint halo CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C3 beginning at approximately 2024-08-08T05:30Z. This event is too faint to confidently track in SOHO LASCO C2 or STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is an M1.3 class flare from AR 3777 (S05W15) peaking at 2024-08-08T04:41Z as seen in SDO AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C3. Event is too faint to reliably track in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, and was extremely faint in SOHO LASCO C3, leading to a highly speculative measurement.

note: Halo CME first seen by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-08T20:00Z, as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The beginning of this event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-08-08T19:38Z to  2024-08-08T22:53Z. The source of this CME is an X1.3 class flare from AR 3777 (S05W25) that peaked at 2024-08-08T19:36Z. This flare can be seen clearly in SDO AIA 94 and 131, along with an EUV wave seen in SDO AIA 193 and 211. Resulting field line opening is also visible in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.
PRELIMINARY SHOCK measurement based on source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C3. This feature was too faint to be reliably tracked in STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-09T01:25Z, as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this event is an eruption of a filament on the NE limb that lifts off at approximately 23:09Z from approximately N40E60 as seen in SDO AIA 304. Field line opening can also be seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284. The first portion of this filament erupts at approximately 22:43Z and resulting in an earlier CME, CME: 2024-08-08T23:24Z which measured below 250 km/s.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. There is no SOHO LASCO C3 data available for this measurement due to a data gap from 2024-08-09T02:24Z to 2024-08-09T04:39Z.

note: A very faint CME with the front best seen in SOHO LASCO C2 but also traceable in a couple of early timestamps in C3. The CME front is not seen in STEREO A (although imagery is available).  No source for the CME was found on disk but there is a tiny post-eruptive arcade seen from behind the west limb in AIA195/131 starting around 2024-08-09T05Z, possibly indicating a source behind the west limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: B/c the CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 (likely because of its faintness) and the source of it has not been found on disk only a plane of sky measurement is definitive. This measurement was done mostly using C2 imagery, so the final CME speed might be a bit higher.

note: An extremely faint CME, barely seen in white light imagery and better seen in difference imagery. No clear source has been found on the Earth-facing disk, however an extremely faint dimming, followed by equally faint post-eruptive arcades is seen in AIA 193/211 centered roughly around (N30E35) starting with 2024-08-09T07Z. There is also a faint movement of field lines behind/on the eastern limb but the fit with two coronagraphs does not fit the close to the limb source.

cmeAnalyses.note: An approximate measurement based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. Weakly confirmed by a very faint dimming centered roughly around N30E35.

note: CME visible to the NE in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The start of the CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real-time due to a data gap from approx. 2024-08-09T11:42Z-16:42Z. The source may be similar to the potential source of CME: 2024-08-09T08:24:00-CME-001, with faint dimming and post-eruptive arcades visible in SDO AIA 193 and 211 around 2024-08-09T09:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on early frames of STEREO A COR2 imagery prior to a data gap and later frames of SOHO LASCO C3 imagery following an earlier data gap. Due to these gaps, the measurement is preliminary and approximate, based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Partial halo CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an M4.5 flare peaking at 2024-08-09T21:23Z from AR 3774 (approx. S05W40). Eruption with rising/opening field lines and dimming are best seen in SDO AIA 193, GOES 284, and STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: SHOCK measurement of the fainter, wider portion of this CME traveling ahead of the leading edge.
Approximate analysis of the narrower brighter bulk that is based on the best fit with two coronagraphs but gives a longitude close to the longitude of the location of the associated flare.

note: Faint CME with a clear front only in a few early timestamps of SOHO LASCO C2 imagery, with fuzzy front in C3 and STEREO A COR2. The clear source is an opening of field lines in SDO AIA 171 beyond NW limb starting at 2024-08-09T23:54Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. The source is far behind the NW limb.

note: Faint CME visible to the NE in STEREO A COR2. It later overlaps in the field of view with CMEs 2024-08-10T03:12Z and 2024-08-10T03:24Z. The CME could not be reliably tracked in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, possibly due to the overlapping features of the later CMEs. The source could not be found, and it may be backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using STEREO A imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME seen to the north in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the NE of STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear, but may be one of a couple faint candidate source eruptions on the disk, best seen in GOES SUVI 284. The first starts around 2024-08-10T02:42Z with dimming near N15W30 starting. There may also be eruptive activity from Active Regions 3781 or 3783 in the NE, seen starting around 2024-08-10T02:34Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. Similar parameters were also obtained in StereoCAT.

note: Partial halo CME faintly seen towards the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the NE of STEREO A COR2. Overlaps in the field of view with CME: 2024-08-10T03:12:00-CME-001. The likely source is an M5.3 flare peaking at 2024-08-10T02:37Z from AR 3780 (approx. S08W02) with associated eruption with dimming and post-eruptive arcades best seen in SDO AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 284. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Bright, slow CME seen to the far north in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is on the far-side of the sun, at an apparent high latitude. Observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and well in GOES SUVI 284 as field lines first opening over the NNE limb around 2024-08-10T22:31Z, and a secondary, wider field line opening starting around 2024-08-11T00:51Z. This eruption is wide and slow, and evolves into a dimpled front in the furthest coronagraph imagery from its the initial frames as the filamentary material is uniquely observed unfurling in coronagraphs.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding a high-latitude far-sided fit. The CME becomes more dimpled and accelerates into later frames, so this fit attempts to best capture the motion of the leading edge.

note: Narrow loop CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and possibly extremely faintly in STEREO A COR2. There is no discernable distinct source. This CME overlaps a overtakes a much slower CME first seen to the west in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-08-10T21:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement of leading edge. Leading edge becomes diffuse halfway through C3 field of view and is not reliably discernable/trackable in STEREO A COR2.

note: Thin CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is uncertain, not directly observed in SDO, GOES, or STEREO A EUV imagery. However, the CME does fit around N20W54 in swpc_cat between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, so this is used as the source, with some medium confidence via the triangulated fit.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, though the front is notably more faint in COR2A and hard to track beyond 10 Rs.

note: This faint CME is seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. No discernable source signatures are visible in SDO AIA or GOES SUVI imagery. This eruption possibly correlates to an estimated M1.0 flare observed in STIX data, with estimated peak time at roughly 2024-08-11T06:24Z and located beyond on SE limb of the Earth-facing disk (on the SW limb as seen from Solar Orbiter). This CME overlaps with CME:2024-08-11T07:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and extremely faintly in STEREO A COR2. This CME overlaps with CME:2024-08-11T07:00Z; both CMEs are believed to be from the same source. No discernable source signatures are visible in SDO AIA or GOES SUVI imagery. This eruption possibly correlates to an estimated M1.0 flare observed in STIX data, with estimated peak time at roughly 2024-08-11T06:24Z and located beyond on SE limb of the Earth-facing disk (on the SW limb as seen from Solar Orbiter).

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: This narrow CME is seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and faintly in STEREO A COR2. The source is a small filament eruption on or just beyond SE limb accompanied by opening field lines, as seen in SDO AIA 304/171/193 starting at about 2024-08-11T09:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint and diffuse leading edge based on best fit between C3 and COR2A, along with approx. source location seen in UV imagery.

note: A very faint seen in STEREO COR2 and SOHO/LASCO but mostly in difference imagery. Its front in SOHO LASCO C2 is very uncertain.  No clear source has been found on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. Source is likely backsided.

note: Faint, jet-like CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. There are no clear source signatures seen on this disk for this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: CME is too faint to reliably measure in SOHO LASCO C3 or STEREO A COR 2, so only SOHO LASCO C2 was used for this measurement. CME was fitting with a range of longitudes (approx. 70 degrees to approx. 110 degrees), and was therefore measured as a plane-of-sky.

note: Thin CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs. Source is a region of the disk centered ~S36E50, with an eruption observed in SDO AIA 304 as thin ejecting filament material and brightening of the surface starting around 2024-08-12T07:33Z, with field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best bit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-12T08:24Z, as well as in later frames by STEREO A COR2. This event was too faint to be seen clearly in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this CME is a small eruption from the vicinity of AR 3785 (S18E45). Material is seen leaving the disk in SDO AIA 304 and minor post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint CME seen to the NE in all coronagraphs. Source is a region of the disk centered ~N35E75, with an eruption observed as brightening of the disk in SDO AIA 304 starting around 2024-08-12T08:42Z, and field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A using the source of N35E75 as a basis, finding some westward deflection in the fit. Half of the front fizzles away in early C2, so this measurement is of the more stable front in the eruption.

note: Narrow, jet-like CME first seen in the S by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-12T12:36Z, as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this eruption is a jet of material seen clearly in GOES SUVI 304 lifting off from approximately originating from approx. S20E90 beginning at approximately 2024-08-12T12:00Z exhibiting strong Southern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Wide CME first seen to the South by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-12T19:00Z as well as in later frames by C3. There is no STEREO A COR2 data available due to a data gap from 2024-08-12T14:38Z to 2024-08-12T22:38Z. Possible source of this eruption is field line opening from AR 3780 (S11W30) exhibiting Southern deflection beginning at approximately 2024-08-12T18:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: PRELIMINARY plane-of-sky due to range of fits and STEREO A COR2 data gap from 2024-08-12T14:38Z to 2024-08-12T22:38Z

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-12T21:48Z as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this event is a jet of material seen in GOES SUVI 304 beginning at approximately 19:30Z from the vicinity of S30W90 but exhibiting Southeastern deflection. Field line opening can also be seen in SDO AIA 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284. There is no STEREO A EUVI data for this source signature due to a data gap from 2024-08-12T14:05Z to 2024-08-12T22:55Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Jet-like CME first seen in the South by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-13T00:12Z, as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this eruption is a thin release of material from approximately S30W90+ that exhibits strong Southeastern deflection as seen in GOES SUVI 304. Field line opening is also visible in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Minor jet CME seen to the south in C2, C3, and COR2A, especially in running difference imagery. May be associated with a very minor eruption at far southern latitudes on the Earth-facing disk seen in 284 around 04:03Z near S70W40.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft measurement of the leading edge based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Jet-like CME first seen in the South by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-13T06:24Z as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is a long, thin eruption off of the SW limb (approx. S30W90+) exhibiting strong Southeastern deflection as seen in GOES SUVI 304. Opening field lines can also be clearly seen in SOD AIA 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.
Approximate analysis based on the source location and confirmed by a good fit with two coronagraphs.

note: A relatively wide CME with the source a slow but relatively significant filament eruption in the SW centered ~S30W45, seen as two waves of ejecta/dimming/opening of field lines/post-eruptive arcades in the SW in AIA 193/304. This is preceded by a C6.6 flare from AR 3780 peaking at 2024-08-14T07:37Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs and on the perceived center of the source filament.

note: A very faint halo, with the front not seen in white light imagery but seen distinctly in SOHO difference imagery, both C2 and C3 (and not only in the early timestamps). The event is fully covered by a large data gap in STEREO A COR2. Its source could potentially be the faint eruption north of AR 3774 centered around (N28E12) and seen as very minor light dimming in AIA 193 between 2024-08-13T08Z and 14Z, however these coronal signatures seem too faint for a noticeable halo. Alternatively, the source could be far-sided. No coronal signatures indicating backsided CME have been found on/behind limb in AIA imagery, but there is a long-duration C8-class flare on the far side seen by STIX instrument on Solar Orbiter and peaking around 13:40Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement assuming far-sided source given no major eruptions on the Earth-facing disk, possibly associated with GONG far-sided spots. Measurement incorporates SOHO C2 and C3 imagery only.

A super speculative one coronagraph analysis assuming front-sided longitude and N of Active Region 3784 as a source. We have no data from STEREO A COR2 for this event b/c of a data gap. The potential front-sided source - some minor activity north of Active Region 3784 - is super minor and seems very suspect. The CME could alternatively be backsided.

note: Narrow jet CME seen to the south in SOHO C2/C3 imagery. The source is not clear as there is no evidence of moving field lines off the southern limb in available GOES/SDO imagers, so potentially the source is located on the far side of the Sun.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO plane of sky measurement as the source longitude is not known and STEREO A imagery is not available at the time of analysis.

note: Fairly narrow CME seen to the north at very high northern latitudes associated with a filament eruption that is seen best in SDO 171/304 after 2024-08-13T18:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made estimating source latitude and longitude based on EUV imagery and use of SOHO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery.

note: Complex CME seen to the southwest made up of several disjoint fronts that all seemingly move together, the leading edge begins to become more diffuse in later frames. Associated with rapidly opening and breaking magnetic field lines near the vicinity of AR3777 (S10W86).

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft measurement using early frames of SOHO/STEREO A which considers multiple disjoint areas of outflow associated with the eruption as one bulk.

note: Jet-like CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is a narrow ejection of material from a small region near S08W70. This small eruption begins at approximately 2024-08-14T02:30Z and appears to exhibit some deflection to the NW as seen in SDO AIA 304. This CME overlaps with CME: 2024-08-14T04:12Z in later frames preventing analysis further into the field of view.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. This CME had already overlapped with CME: 2024-08-14T04:12Z by the time it was visible in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Jet-like CME first seen to the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-14T03:48Z as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source appears to be a small filament eruption located at approx. S30W100 beginning around 2024-08-14T01:50Z exhibiting a more Southern deflection as seen in SDO AIA and STEREO A EUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery. The source is likely an M4.4 flare and eruption from Active Region 13777 (S04W89) starting around 2024-08-14T03:40Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. An opening of field lines is visible near the western limb at this time in SDO AIA 171 and 193, and post-eruptive arcades begin to form around 05:30Z as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the bulk portion based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: First CME in a series of consecutive CMEs to the west in both coronagraphs. No coronal signatures on disk have been found; there are some coronal signatures indicating that there were multiple eruptions around this time on/behind the limb, but these consecutive CMEs do not fit with two coronagraphs with longitudes close to/above 90 degrees.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. No clear on-disk coronal signatures have been found for this CME.

note: This CME is visible as a partial halo directed towards the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is visible mostly to the northeast in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an X1.1 flare and eruption from Active Region 13784 (N14E03) starting around 2024-08-14T06:27Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Dimming is observed in SDO AIA 171 and 193 surrounding the eruption site, and post-eruptive arcades begin to form around 08:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the brighter, bulk portion based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Multiple measurements resulted in speeds ranging from 514 to 700 km/s.

note: Faint jet-like CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-14T09:12Z as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. There is no clear source seen on the Earth facing disk, however some faint field line opening can be seen in SDO AIA 193, leading to a likely far sided source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Second in a series of consecutive CMEs to the west in both coronagraphs with no coronal signatures on disk but measuring about 65 deg long.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. No clear on-disk coronal signatures have been found for this CME.

note: Third in a series of consecutive CMEs to the west in both coronagraphs with no coronal signatures on disk but measuring about 65 deg long.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. No clear on-disk coronal signatures have been found for this CME.

note: Forth in a series of consecutive CMEs to the west in both coronagraphs with no coronal signatures on disk but measuring about 65 deg long.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. No clear on-disk coronal signatures have been found for this CME.

note: Extremely faint and narrow CME seen to the E in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2. Extremely faint in C3. Source is opening field lines on the E limb seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-08-14T23:30Z, from AR 13790 (S10E80).

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement of extremely diffuse leading edge. Only two frames of COR2A, two frames of C2, and one frame of C3 were able to be used due to the faintness of the event. However, the best fit parameters match the candidate source location well.

note: Extremely faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Exact source is uncertain, but is likely associated with the continuous field line movement seen on the west limb in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of extremely faint leading edge using best fit between coronagraphs.

note: Bright CME in the NW with the clear source a beautiful "loop" eruption on/just behind the NW limb starting around 2024-08-15T09:30Z as seen in AIA 304/171 and SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. The CME seems to be more far-sided that the apparent source of this CME - a loop on/behind the NW limb seen in AIA imagery.

note: Faint and narrow CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Not visible in COR2 due to a data gap in STEREO A lasting from 2024-08-15T17:53Z to 2024-08-15T22:23Z and due to the faintness of this event. Source is a small eruption seen from beyond the N/NE limb starting at 2024-08-15T18:03Z in SDO AIA 304, at an apparent latitude of N60. Small amount of ejecta seen in SDO AIA 171 starting at 18:18Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using C2 and C3. This CME is not visible in COR2 due to a data gap in STEREO A lasting from 2024-08-15T17:53Z to 2024-08-15T22:23Z and due to the faintness of this event.

note: Jet-like CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-16T02:00Z as well as in later frames by SOHO LASCO C3. This event is too faint to be reliably tracked in STEREO A COR2. There is not distinct source seen for this event however small eruptive activity is seen in the vicinity of AR 3790 (S14E70) at this time as seen in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2. This event was too faint to be reliably tracked in C3 or STEREO A COR2.

note: Slow streamer blowout CME first seen in the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at approximately 2024-08-16T10:00Z as well as in later frames by C3 and STEREO A COR2. Field line loop movement can be seen around the central West limb in GOES SUVI 171 and 284. A second more inner loop can be seen as part of this structure, however outermore feature is much more pronounced.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME visible to the W/NW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be the M1.3 flare from AR13780, however there are moving/opening field lines visible beyond the NW limb starting around 2024-08-16T13:31Z in GOES SUVI 284 that could also be a potential source for this CME. For this analysis, the M1.3 location was used with potential northern deflection visible in SDO/AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. Additional analysis with far-sided longitudes were completed, however the fits had more uncertainty with it compared to the fits using longitudes near AR13780.

note: CME seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and NE in STEREO COR2A. The source is an eruption from AR 3789 starting around 2024-08-16T13:52Z as field line movement and ejecting material in SDO AIA 171/193/211/304, alongside a C5.9 class flare which peaked at 2024-08-16T14:09Z best seen in SDO AIA 131. Eruption on the north end of the AR. Light dimming also observed reverberating across a broad area NE of the region in SDO AIA 193/211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A of early frames due to current availability. Deflected far northward of the eruption centered around N28E04 in SDO imagery, but it triangulated here between coronagraphs so it is in good confidence.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR 2 imagery for a few frames prior to a data gap starting at 2024-08-16T17:53Z. The source is likely related to a small eruption near Active Region 13780 (S10E85) starting around 2024-08-16T15:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to a small eruption near the western limb starting around 2024-08-17T06:20Z seen best in SDO AIA 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. The source is likely an M1.6 flare and eruption from Active Region 13784 (N17W41) starting around 2024-08-17T10:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Faint dimming is visible northwest of the eruption site in SDO AIA 193 shortly after the flare is observed.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. This event is faint and is therefore not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery. This measurement relies on SOHO LASCO C2 imagery only and the measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the north in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and a few frames among a data gap in STEREO A COR2 data. The frames in STEREO A COR2 are fairly noisy during this event. The source of this CME could potentially be a filament eruption visible along the N/NW limb believed to be on the far-side of the sun as seen in SDO/AIA 304. There are a few fronts visible in the coronagraphs that appear associated with this eruption, this front is first seen starting around 16:00Z while an earlier much slower front is seen starting around 15:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters are based on best fit of feature using the possible source with notable deflection to the NE.

note: This CME is faintly visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and a few frames within a data gap of STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be filament ejecta visible along the western limb starting around 2024-08-17T18:53Z best seen in SDO/AIA and GOES SUVI 304. There are moving/opening field lines also visible starting around 2024-08-17T19:00Z in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on a plane-of-sky fit due to lack of usable STEREO A COR2 imagery to triangulate the direction of the CME and the lack of visibility of the exact source location.

note: A very faint CME following the faster 2024-08-17T19:12Z CME. This CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO and its front is not seen in white light imagery in any coronagraph. It is not clearly seen in C2 difference imagery, but is seen in C3 difference imagery as a separate CME. No source has been found in the EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is possible b/c the CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A and no source has been found in EUV imagery

note: The start of this CME is likely much earlier but the front is not seen in C2. It is another (the narrowest) outflow from the fast 2024-08-17T19:12Z CME. The start of this CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2; its front is not seen in C2 difference imagery, but is seen in C3 and later COR2A difference imagery as a narrow blip. No source has been found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very approximate measurement based on a fit with two coronagraphs. No source has been found and fronts are very faint and fuzzy in both coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2. Source is an eruption from just beyond the SE limb. Ejecta and opening field lines can be seen in SDO AIA 131/171/304 imagery staring at 2024-08-18T19:30Z at an apparent latitude of S20. Data gap in STEREO A lasting from 2023-08-18T14:23Z to 2024-08-18T22:38Z obscures a few early STEREO A frames of this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between coronagraphs and location of source as seen in UV imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames before the leading edge becomes too diffuse to follow. The source is likely related to faint field line movement visible near the southwest limb in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193 imagery starting around 2024-08-19T08:40Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Because the source location is unclear and the leading edge is diffuse an difficult to measure, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as a wide opening of field lines are visible beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-08-19T12:20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Because the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: Faint CME visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This CME partially overlaps with CME 2024-08-19T12:36Z. The source is likely far-sided as faint opening of field lines are visible beyond the northwest limb, just north of the opening field lines attributed to the overlapping CME, in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-08-19T12:20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The leading edge becomes too diffuse to track just before reaching halfway through the C3 field of view. Several STEREO A COR2 images were able to be used, but poor quality/pixilation of STEREO A COR2 difference imagery after the frame timestamped 2024-08-19T15:38Z hindered proper tracking of the leading edge in these frames.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is not clear. There is filament ejecta visible to the S/SE starting around 2024-08-20T16:45Z which isn't best for timing, however with limited stereoscopic viewpoints of the solar disk, it's possible there was an earlier eruption and the filament ejecta was seen later, this is very speculative though.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of features in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Loop CME visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge becomes diffuse towards the end of the COR2A field of view. There is no clear source for this CME on the disk in UV imagery and therefore is likely farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. There was some northern deflection seen especially in C2. The leading edge becomes too diffuse to track just before reaching the end of the COR2A field of view.

note: The first of three overlapping CMEs seen to the West in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is opening field lines from just beyond the West limb at an apparent latitude of S10 seen starting at 2024-08-19T21:49Z in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using best fit between C3 and COR2A.

note: The second of three overlapping CMEs, seen to the Northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is wide but extremely faint opening field lines seen on or possibly just beyond the Northwest limb seen starting at 2024-08-19T21:03Z in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using best fit between C2, C3 and COR2A. The faint leading edge was easiest to track in C2 and COR2A, so these were mainly used to determine the best fit parameters. The leading edge is extremely faint and partially obstructed by the pylon in C3, but the faint leading edge feature is just distinct enough in C3 to be trackable.

note: The third of three overlapping CMEs, seen to the Southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is widely and distinctly opening field lines from beyond the Southwest limb seen starting at 2024-08-19T21:54Z in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using best fit between C3 and COR2A. The leading edge is brighter and more well-defined in COR2A than in C3, but there is still a very faint leading edge visible in C3.

note: Faint CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs, but weakly in SOHO LASCO C3 as it fades. The source for this CME is uncertain, as the only observed source of field line movement starts around 2024-08-20T00:12Z in SDO AIA 193 over the NW limb, at the same time the CME is visible in SOHO LASCO C2, making it unlikely.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO COR2A for a good far-sided fit despite the unclear source. This event becomes too faint and goes into the pylon in C3, giving no usable imagery.

note: This CME is brightly visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is not clear, but may be associated with faintly visible slow moving field lines along the SE limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-08-19T23:00Z. There is a dimming visible on the disk to the NE of AR 13790 starting around 2024-08-20T00:40Z, however the directionality of the dimming does not correlate well with the directionality of the CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based off of a best fit of the CME in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. There are possibly overlapping features included in this analysis. The CME appears to speed up in later frames, so earlier frames were not included in this analysis.

note: Faint CME to the east with the possible source a some dimming on/near East limb.

Faint, fast CME seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO COR2A is not in a data gap but does not observe this CME, likely due to the faint nature. The source for this CME is uncertain, and may only be observed in SDO AIA 171 around 2024-08-20T07:12Z as some dimming in the field lines over the SE limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement due to the uncertain source location and lack of CME visibility in STEREO COR2A imagery.

note: Wide CME first seen in the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-20T11:48Z as well as in later frames by C3 and STERO A COR2. There is no clear source on the disk for this event, however some faint field line movement can be seen in GOES SUVI 284, so this is likely a far sided event. This CME partially overlaps with CME: 2024-08-20T12:12Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint jet in the southeast. No source has been found on the Earth-facing disk.

CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-20T12:12Z as well as in later frames by C3 and STERO A COR2. The source of this eruption is a filament eruption just beyond the West limb (approx. S30W120) as seen in STEREO A EUVI 304. Wide opening field lines can also be seen in SDO AIA 94, 171, 192 and GOES SUVI 284. This CME partially overlaps with CME: 2024-08-20T11:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STERO A COR2.

note: A narrow faint CME/outflow in the wake of the 2024-08-20T12:12Z farsided CME. Source could be a faint movement of field lines behind the SSW limb seen in AIA 193 after 12:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided, but there are rising loops visible near Active Region 13785 (S15W80) starting around 2024-08-20T21:12Z in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery which may or may not be related to this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using STEREO A COR2 imagery with a longitude of 113 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location. Additionally, this event is very faint and cannot be measured reliably using SOHO imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided, and very faint field line movement is visible beyond the western limb in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-08-21T02:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Because the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: A faint CME to the E seen in both coronagraphs with the likely source a minor on-limb filament eruption in the New (unnumbered) AR on the SE limb (S10E77) seen in AIA 304 at 04:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: A very faint minor CME to the northwest only seen in early timestamps of SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, and mostly in difference imagery. It is fully obscured by pylon in C3. Two possible sources are minor activity in AR 3789 (N24W56) and in AR 3784 (N16W87).

cmeAnalyses.note: Since there is a range of possible sources, POS analysis is the most reliable one.

note: Narrow CME seen to the east in SOHO C2/C3 imagery, likely associated with a minor eruption from near AR3799 (S20E70) as evidenced by moving field lines in GOES 284 and a brightening in the region.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading measurement of the jet-like narrow CME using two frames of SOHO C3 and several frames of SOHO C2 as well as knowledge of the source latitude and longitude.

note: Bright loop CME first seen in the NW by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2024-08-22T06:53Z. Data gap in SOHO LASCO imagery from 2024-08-21T23:36Z to 2024-08-22T07:24Z obstructed a few early frames of this CME in C2. The source of this event appears to be a large far sided eruption evidenced by wide opening field lines seen in GOES SUVI 284 beginning at approximately 2024-08-22T06:19Z and the possible remanence of filament material seen in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of bright leading edge using best fit between coronagraphs and farsided parameters as indicated by UV imagery.

note: CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-22T10:00Z. The source of this event is a C5.6 flare from AR 3801 (N09E71) peaking at 2024-08-22T08:08Z seen in SDO AIA 131. Field line opening is also seen in GOES SUVI 284

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: A very complex CME with a wider fainter partial halo component (possible shock) and a narrower complex-shaped brighter portion that potentially has several lobes. No corresponding source has been found on the Earth-facing disk. There was an equivalent of an M3 class flare seen by STIX instrument on the Solar Orbiter peaking at 2024-08-22T14:37Z with the very approximate longitude of 180, which could be the far sided possible source of this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of two bright overlapping lobes that appear to travel together as one unit at the same rate, using best fit between coronagraphs and farsided parameters as indicated by UV imagery.
An approximate analysis based on the best possible fit with two coronagraphs. Front-sided longitudes don't produce a fit at all.

note: Faint partial halo CME visible to the west/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of the CME may be a filament and possible flare starting around 2024-08-23T01:00Z from AR13794 (N20W30) based on SDO/AIA 131 and 304. Dimming is also visible to the SW of the eruption location - best seen in SDO/AIA 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the north in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and northwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and therefore unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding source signatures on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and for 2 brief frames to the S in STEREO COR2A as it was in a lengthy data gap over this CME duration. The source for this CME is uncertain, but thanks to the two frames in STEREO COR2A a triangulation was made around S42W24 via swpc_cat, with some speculation due to the single-frame triangulation.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement with one usable frame of STEREO COR2A with SOHO LASCO C3, finding a good match at S42W24 despite the lack of an EUV-observed source at this time at this location. As such, this analysis is fairly speculative, but the best which can be done in real-time.

note: Fast, faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The source appears to be jet-like filament eruptions on or around the west limb, best observed in GOES SUVI 284 at 2024-08-23T14:56Z, with a second one at 16:20Z less likely due to timing.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 as the source is on/just beyond the west limb, with no STEREO COR2A data available to triangulate.

note: Faint CME seen to the S in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, though very faint in C2 to the point of being unable to distinctively define its start time around the occulting disk, so T17:24Z was used as the best reference for visibility in C2. No source observed for this CME in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 as the source is uncertain with no STEREO COR2A data available to triangulate.

note: CME seen to the NE in all coronagraphs. The source appears to be far-sided, observed best as field line movement on the east limb starting around 2024-08-24T20:18Z in SDO AIA 171, likely deflecting northward observing its travel path from SOHO LASCO C2 to C3.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement due to the unknown likely far-sided source, and a poor fit between SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO COR2A individually, likely due to the observed northward deflection observed as the front travels from C2->C3.
Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs (since the source is backsided). Analysis focuses on two lobes of this CME, which move in unison.

note: Streamer blowout CME to the S/SE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The start time of the CME could be as early as ~10Z, as that's when the shape first starts appearing in difference imagery, however it doesn't quite start progressing out in the field of view until roughly 12:12Z. The source appears to be moving/opening field lines visible in GOES SUVI 284 in the SE quadrant of the Earth-facing disk with notable changes in the corona's structure over the course of several hours. Most notably, these changes are visible starting around 14:00Z. Brightening is visible on the disk starting around 15:00Z with continued restructuring of the corona for several hours after. Additionally, the CME structure appears to be visible in the field lines off the SE limb, fairly stationary as early as 2024-08-25T17:00Z and is released during this restructuring starting around 2024-08-26T12:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Bright CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-28T04:12Z as well as by C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is the eruption of a loop like filament sitting on or just beyond the East limb centered at approximately S10E90 as seen in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304. Field line opening is also visible in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, GOES SUVIE 284 and STEREO A EUVI 195, along with post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 94 and 131. This filament erupted in two portions, the first appearing as a streamer outflow, followed my the main expulsion of material. In the coronagraphs, this appears as two leading edges, a further out one that is lopsided and faint and a closer in one that is more central and bright. Parameters of this event are based on the more central, brightest portion of this CME, as that is where the bulk of the material resides.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME had not developed fully in SOHO LASCO C2 frames and was not well representative of the overall features, so only C3 and COR2A were used for this measurement. A slightly faster, more narrow and fainter feature is also observed ahead of the main bulk of this CME but has been deemed inconsequential.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-28T11:48Z as well as by C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. There is no clear source seen on the disk apart from some minor field line movement seen in the NE in SDO AIA 171. Event does not exhibit a clear and distinct leading edge.

cmeAnalyses.note: STA POS measurement due to lake of usable SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery and uncertain source location.

note: CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-28T12:48Z as well as by C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. A majority of this CME is obscured by data gaps (SOHO: 28/14:36Z to 29/04:35Z, COR2A: 28/14:23Z to 28/23:09Z), so analysis of this event is based solely on later frames of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this event is dimming seen around N45W40 as seen in SDO AIA 211 beginning at approximately 28/11:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. A number of StereoCAT measurement were also taken yielding a lat/lon parameter range of 45-50/40-55 and a speed range of 330-363 km/s.

note: CME first seen in the SE by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2024-08-28T18:15Z. There is no SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery available for this event due to a data gap from 28/14:36Z to 29/04:35Z. The source of this CME is clear opening field lines seen along the SE limb by SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284, likely representing a far sided source. However the CME itself is fairly faint.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to lack of SOHO LASCO triangulation. Longitudes between approx. -60 and -100 degrees yielded plausible fits, however source does indicate a far sided eruption.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-08-29T05:17Z as well as by C3 and STERO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is field line opening that appears to stretch from an area of dimming just NE of AR 3803 at approx. N20E60, to beyond the East limb. This field line movement begins at approximately 2024-08-29T04:08Z as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 195. Post eruptive arcades are also visible in SDO AIA 94 and 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: A very faint CME to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2. The source is likely a super minor eruption off/behind the northeast limb seen after 2024-08-29T18:45Z in AIA 304 and as minor moving/opening of field lines in AIA 193. The CME is covered in STEREO A COR2 by a data gap and is seen very faintly in C3.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 because of a data gap, so only POS measurement is definitive.

note: A very faint minor CME only seen in a few early timestamps in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraphs. The front is too faint in C3 to trace it. No source was found on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: An approximate measurement based on fitting of front in two coronagraphs. The longitude could be higher (a fir with 125 deg longitude is also good).

note: Faint CME in the northeast with the source a minor filament eruption centered around N22E47 (spanning N12E30 to N39E50) and seen lifting off at 2024-08-29T23:21Z in AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and confirmed by the location of the likely source (filament eruption).

note: Faint CME to the southeast. There may be two lobes (earlier more eastern and another, possibly narrower on, directed somewhat more southwardly). The source is a fast opening/movement of field lines/dimming in the corona behind the limb directed towards the SE seen in AIA 193 at 2024-08-30T12:27Z which is associated with the M3.8 flare peaking at 2024-08-30T12:20Z. There is also a slightly later slower eruption on/behind the SE limb seen in AIA 193 after 2024-08-30T12:30Z, with a minor ejecta best seen in AIA 304, followed by an opening of field lines behind the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis of the outer front of this CME based on the fit with two coronagraphs and confirmed by the location of the associated flare. There is also a fuzzy more inward narrower front, directed somewhat more southerward.

note: CME seen to the W in all coronagraphs, but best in STEREO COR2A. The source is not completely clear, and may be a part of some field line movement on/around the west limb in SDO AIA 171 beginning as early as 2024-08-30T18:22Z. This CME is notably extremely faint in SOHO imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analyzed as a STEREO COR2A Plane-of-Sky, with its plane of sky sitting at W114.03 at this time. Despite the speed, the CME front is quite diffuse in COR2A, and barely observable in SOHO LASCO C2 and especially C3 currently mid-campaign. There is too much uncertainty to be able to say for certain we are tracking the CME front properly between spacecraft.

note: CME seen to the NE in all coronagraphs. The source is likely a filament eruption just NE of AR 13804, beginning around 2024-08-30T22:48Z and centered around N20E28. Observed as filament material ejecting and brightening in SDO AIA 304, and field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best possible triangulation of this CME front with STEREO COR2A and limited SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to an ongoing SOHO campaign, using the source filament eruption as a basis and finding some deflection.

note: Bright CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs. The source is far-sided, observed best as field line movement over the NW limb in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-08-31T00:12Z, with initial more southern movement seen starting around 2024-08-30T23:42Z which likely resulted in CME 2024-08-31T01:38Z. This CME's parameters are difficult to pin down, due to an ongoing campaign with SOHO impacting available LASCO C2/C3 imagery for triangulation with STEREO COR2A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best possible triangulation of this CME front with STEREO COR2A and limited SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to an ongoing SOHO campaign, coupled with the observed but unclear location of the far-sided source eruption in SDO imagery.

note: Bright CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs. The source is far-sided, observed best as field line movement over the NW limb in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-08-30T23:42Z, with secondary more northern movement seen starting around 2024-08-31T00:12Z which likely resulted in 2024-08-31T00:53Z. This CME's parameters are difficult to pin down, due to an ongoing campaign with SOHO impacting available LASCO C2/C3 imagery for triangulation with STEREO COR2A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best possible triangulation of this CME front with STEREO COR2A and limited SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to an ongoing SOHO campaign, coupled with the observed but unclear location of the far-sided source eruption in SDO imagery.

note: This asymmetrical shaped CME is visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is a data gap in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery due to a campaign. The source appears to be moving/opening field lines from beyond the NE limb in SDO/AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-08-31T11:09Z. Multiple loops are seen rising in SDO/AIA 171 which may contribute to the appearance of multiple fronts in coronagraph imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters are based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery with a small portion of the asymmetrical lobe/front excluded due to measurement technique limitations.
